title: How to Remove Blood Stains from Wood

steps.headline: Sprinkle baking soda onto the blood stain.
Soak a brush in white vinegar.
Use the brush to gently rub the stained area.
Wipe the affected area thoroughly with a dry clean cloth.
steps.description: If the stain is still visible, use bleach. Use bleach cautiously especially if you have dark wood.

steps.headline: Soak a brush in bleach and wipe it all over the stained area.
Rinse the area thoroughly using a damp cloth to remove any residue.
Dry the wood using a towel or cloth.
Use a clean cloth to blot the excess blood.
Mix 1/2 tablespoon of liquid dish-washing detergent with 1 cup of cold water in a small bowl to make a detergent solution.
Dip a clean cloth in the detergent solution.
Wipe the stained area with the cloth to remove the remaining blood stain.
Rinse the area thoroughly using a damp cloth to remove any residue.
Dry the wood using a towel or cloth.
steps.description: Check if the blood stain is still visible.

steps.headline: If the stain is still noticeable, dip a superfine steel wool (number 0000) in liquid wax.
Rub the stained area lightly with the steel wool.
steps.description: The steel wool should remove only a fine layer of the surface of the wood.

steps.headline: Wipe the surface clean with a soft cloth.
Wax or polish the surface if needed.
Wipe the blood with a damp sponge.
Rinse the sponge.
steps.description: Repeat the wiping process until all the blood is gone.

steps.headline: Rinse the area thoroughly using a damp cloth to remove any remaining blood stain.
Dry the wood using a towel or cloth.
Buff the affected area with a cloth moistened with mineral spirits.
Use a clean, wet cloth to wipe the area.
steps.description: If the blood stain is still visible, repeat the process using a steel wool (number 0000).

steps.headline: Rub the stained area using a steel wool moistened with mineral spirits.
steps.description: Do this lightly and make sure you rub along the grain of the wood. Try to remove only as much finish as you have to.

steps.headline: Wipe the surface clean with a soft cloth.
Refinish the affected area after 24 hours, if needed.

text: Untreated Wood Sprinkle baking soda onto the blood stain.  Soak a brush in white vinegar.  Use the brush to gently rub the stained area.  Wipe the affected area thoroughly with a dry clean cloth. If the stain is still visible, use bleach. Use bleach cautiously especially if you have dark wood. Soak a brush in bleach and wipe it all over the stained area.  Rinse the area thoroughly using a damp cloth to remove any residue.  Dry the wood using a towel or cloth.  Waxed or Polished Wood Use a clean cloth to blot the excess blood.  Mix 1/2 tablespoon of liquid dish-washing detergent with 1 cup of cold water in a small bowl to make a detergent solution.  Dip a clean cloth in the detergent solution.  Wipe the stained area with the cloth to remove the remaining blood stain.  Rinse the area thoroughly using a damp cloth to remove any residue.  Dry the wood using a towel or cloth. Check if the blood stain is still visible. If the stain is still noticeable, dip a superfine steel wool (number 0000) in liquid wax.  Rub the stained area lightly with the steel wool. The steel wool should remove only a fine layer of the surface of the wood. Wipe the surface clean with a soft cloth.  Wax or polish the surface if needed.  Varnished Wood Wipe the blood with a damp sponge.  Rinse the sponge. Repeat the wiping process until all the blood is gone. Rinse the area thoroughly using a damp cloth to remove any remaining blood stain.  Dry the wood using a towel or cloth.  Buff the affected area with a cloth moistened with mineral spirits. Do this lightly. Use a clean, wet cloth to wipe the area. If the blood stain is still visible, repeat the process using a steel wool (number 0000). Rub the stained area using a steel wool moistened with mineral spirits. Do this lightly and make sure you rub along the grain of the wood. Try to remove only as much finish as you have to. Wipe the surface clean with a soft cloth.  Refinish the affected area after 24 hours, if needed.
sentences: Untreated Wood Sprinkle baking soda onto the blood stain.
Soak a brush in white vinegar.
Use the brush to gently rub the stained area.
Wipe the affected area thoroughly with a dry clean cloth.
If the stain is still visible, use bleach.
Use bleach cautiously especially if you have dark wood.
Soak a brush in bleach and wipe it all over the stained area.
Rinse the area thoroughly using a damp cloth to remove any residue.
Dry the wood using a towel or cloth.
Waxed or Polished Wood Use a clean cloth to blot the excess blood.
Mix 1/2 tablespoon of liquid dish-washing detergent with 1 cup of cold water in a small bowl to make a detergent solution.
Dip a clean cloth in the detergent solution.
Wipe the stained area with the cloth to remove the remaining blood stain.
Rinse the area thoroughly using a damp cloth to remove any residue.
Dry the wood using a towel or cloth.
Check if the blood stain is still visible.
If the stain is still noticeable, dip a superfine steel wool (number 0000) in liquid wax.
Rub the stained area lightly with the steel wool.
The steel wool should remove only a fine layer of the surface of the wood.
Wipe the surface clean with a soft cloth.
Wax or polish the surface if needed.
Varnished Wood Wipe the blood with a damp sponge.
Rinse the sponge.
Repeat the wiping process until all the blood is gone.
Rinse the area thoroughly using a damp cloth to remove any remaining blood stain.
Dry the wood using a towel or cloth.
Buff the affected area with a cloth moistened with mineral spirits.
Do this lightly.
Use a clean, wet cloth to wipe the area.
If the blood stain is still visible, repeat the process using a steel wool (number 0000).
Rub the stained area using a steel wool moistened with mineral spirits.
Do this lightly and make sure you rub along the grain of the wood.
Try to remove only as much finish as you have to.
Wipe the surface clean with a soft cloth.
Refinish the affected area after 24 hours, if needed.
